title-group.article-title: Investigation of extensional rheological behaviors of polypropylene for foaming

article-meta.aff: Shanghai Key Laboratory of Advanced Polymeric Materials, Key Laboratory for Ultrafine Materials of Ministry of Education, School of Materials Science and Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai, P.R.China

author-notes.corresp: Anna Zheng, Shanghai Key Laboratory of Advanced Polymeric Materials, Key Laboratory for Ultrafine Materials of Ministry of Education, School of Materials Science and Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai 200237, P.R.China. Email: zan@ecust.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This study investigated the relationship between the extensional rheological behaviors and the foamability of polypropylenes (PPs). Both the shear and extensional rheological properties of four types of PPs with different molecular structures (linear PP, linear PP with high-molecular component, long-chain-branched PP, and cross-linked PP) were tested by rheometers and the PPs were foamed by batch process with supercritical carbon dioxide as foam agent. It was found that when the PP showed strain-hardening behavior at certain strain rates (on the order of 1 s−1), the obtained foams had high expansion ratio and fine cell structures. Otherwise, the strain-hardening behavior of PP had limited effects on the foamability. In addition, a theoretical analysis suggested that the strain-hardening behavior provided higher melt strength and simultaneously changed the rupture behavior of the melt, thus the gas bubble could be stable during expansion step and the cellular structure was generated. The foamability of PPs can be predicted from the extensional properties without considering their molecular structures.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: A plastic foam material consists of a solid plastic phase with the interior dispersed with gas. This type of material is light in weight, and it has a variety of uses that include thermal and acoustic insulation, core materials for sandwich panels, furniture parts, and flotation materials. Most commercially available foams are polystyrene (PS) and polyethylene (PE) foams. Polypropylene (PP) foams have some unique advantages over PS and PE foams, such as higher temperature resistance, good stiffness, excellent chemical resistance, and good impact strength, which make them attractive for foaming applications.1

The PP foaming process consists of three steps: (a) the formation of the gas/polymer solution; (b) the generation of the nucleus of the bubbles and their expansion; and (c) the solidification of the bubbles.

In the expansion step, the solubility of the gas in the polymer melts decreases because of the pressure drop or the temperature increase during the process. Overloaded gas begins to diffuse into the formed bubble nucleus. From the cells model,2 polymer melts are like shells packing the bubbles with growing nuclei. If the shells of the melt are not strong enough, the bubbles will collapse and can no longer form a foam structure. Unfortunately, most linear PP (L-PP) melt shells have such weakness.

To increase the melt strength of the PP, commercial L-PP must be modified. Four approaches are commonly used to improve the melt strength of PP: increasing its molecular weight, increasing its molecular weight distribution, introducing long-chain branches, and cross-linking.

Numerous research projects have been conducted for this purpose, and most of the researchers focus on the difference in the rheological properties between L-PP and modified PP.3–6 Other researchers are more interested in improving the foamability by introducing modified PP with a high melt strength.7–13 Meanwhile, many types of PPs with high melt strength are available,14–19 but some modified PPs have either a very narrow foam-processing window or are not suitable for foaming at all. Few studies investigated the appropriate rheological properties for foaming. Therefore, establishing the relationship between suitable rheological properties and foamability of PP is important.

To date, the investigations in this field are rarely reported. Park used the loss angle (tan δ) to assess the foamability of PP and obtained a foamability factor F = ρD(tan δ)0.75 ≤ 1.8, where ρ was the foam density and D was the average diameter of the cell.20 The factor was related to the final cell diameter, and therefore, it could not be used for predictions. Gendron defined a foam-processing window for poly(ethylene-co-octene) using complex viscosity and tan δ, which was merely a phenomenological analysis from the experimental results.21 Yamaguchi studied rheological properties and foam processability for blends of linear and cross-linked polyolefins.22,23 Michaeli first proposed to assess the foamability of PP from biaxial extensional behavior, but the results were quite brief.24 Münstedt also noted that the prediction of the foamability could be made from uniaxial extensional viscosity, a more reliable parameter than the biaxial extensional viscosity. However, his results were based on only one type of branched PP and its blends with a L-PP.25 Stange investigated a series of PPs and concluded that, in addition to the melt strength, the strain hardening at high strain rates had an important effect on the final expansion ratio.26

In this study, we aimed to obtain suitable extensional rheological behaviors for foaming PP and to verify the validity and universality of the results. Therefore, the rheological behaviors of four types of PPs with different molecular structures were investigated. The PPs were subsequently foamed in the batch process using supercritical carbon dioxide (CO2) under the same foaming process conditions. The foaming behaviors related to their rheological properties were systematically discussed. Finally, based on the analysis of the foam structures, suitable rheological behaviors for the foamability of PPs were concluded.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: The commercial Y-1600 L-PP supplied by the Jinshan Petrochemical Company has a melt flow index (MFI) of 16.
The commercial RS1684 L-PP with high-molecular PE component (HMC-PP) supplied by the Basell Company has an MFI of 1.6.
The commercial PF-814 long-chain-branched PP (LCB-PP) supplied by the Basell Company has an MFI of 2.
The self-prepared, cross-linked PP (C-PP)13 containing 47.6% weight fraction of gel has an MFI of 0.2.

All the MFI experiments were conducted at 230℃ under a fixed load of 2.16 kg. Material properties are listed in Table 1. Table 1.
Material properties.
Sample Mw Mw/Mn λa Gel% Mcb Tm (℃) Tc (℃)
L-PP 193243 4.0 – – 166.4 111.6
HMC-PP 400589 13.5 – 155.6 110.1
LCB-PP 305589 5.4 0.31 158.7 124.4
C-PP 292050c 4.2 – 47.6 72000 165.9 122.9
a
Number of long-chain branches per 1000 monomer units according to Ref. [27]. b
Average molecular weight between two cross-linking points. c
Mw of the precursor of the C-PP.
PP: polypropylenes; L-PP: linear PP; HMC-PP: high-molecular PE component; LCB-PP: long-chain branched PP; C-PP: cross-linked PP.

sec.title: Differential scanning calorimetry measurements
sec.p: The temperature and heat flow area of the calorimeter were calibrated with indium before performing the analysis. The samples (approximately 10 mg) were sealed in an aluminum pan and heated or cooled in a nitrogen atmosphere. Initially, the samples were heated from room temperature to 200℃ at a rate of 10℃ min−1. They were then held isothermally for 10 min to destroy any residual nuclei before being cooled at a rate of 10℃ min−1 to obtain the crystallization temperature (Tc). The samples were reheated to 200℃ at a rate of 10℃ min−1 to obtain the melt temperature (Tm).

sec.title: Molecular structure characterization
sec.p: High temperature gel permeation chromatography (HT-GPC) analysis was conducted using 1,2,4-trichlorobenzene (TCB) at 150℃ at 1 mL min−1 using a Viscotek 350 A HT-GPC system. The PP (0.1 g) was completely dissolved in 100 mL of TCB containing 0.1 wt% butyl hydroxy toluene. The equipment responses were calibrated using standard samples before testing. These results contain a determination of the number average and the weight average molecular mass, Mn and Mw, respectively, and the polydispersity index Mw/Mn.

The products of the reaction were extracted using the Soxhlet method. Approximately 0.5 g of the sample was cut into small pieces, packaged in a copper cloth of 250 mesh and extracted with reﬂuxing xylene for 12 h in a Soxhlet extractor. The undissolved part (gel) was dried in a vacuum oven at 80℃ for 24 h. Then, the above process was repeated until the weight of the gel no longer varied. The percentage of the gel in the samples was calculated using the following formula: (1)Gel percentage=gel weightinitial weight×100%
The extraction process was performed three times for each sample, and the average percentage of gel was calculated.

The degree of swelling (Q) and the average molecular weight between the cross-linking points MC were calculated using equations (2) and (3) (2)Q=(W1/ρ1+W2/ρ2)/(W2/ρ2) (3)Mc¯=p2V1Q5312-χ W1 and W2 are the mass (g) of the solvent and the polymer in the swollen gel, respectively. ρ1 and ρ2 are the density (g cm−3) of the solvent and the origin polymer, respectively. V1 is the specific molar volume (mL mol−1) of the solvent. χ is the Flory–Huggins interaction parameter. In all calculations, ρ1 = 0.86 g cm−3, ρ2 = 0.91 g cm−3, V1 = 136 mL mol−1 and χ = 0.43, as listed in the Polymer Handbook.27

sec.title: Shear rheological measurements
sec.p: The rheological behaviors of the samples were investigated at 180℃ using a controlled stress (500 Pa) rheometer (Therm Hakke 6.0) in the oscillatory mode. The parallel plate fixtures were 20 mm in diameter at a gap of 1 mm. All measurements were carried out under a nitrogen atmosphere. Time sweeps confirmed that the sample did not degrade during testing. Stress sweeps were performed to ensure the measurements were within the linear viscoelastic regime. The complex viscosity (η*) was measured at frequencies ranging from 0.0628 to 628 rad s−1 as a function of the angular frequency (ω).

sec.title: Extensional viscosity measurements
sec.p: The ARES rotational rheometer (TA Instrument) with a sentmanat extensional rheometer was used to measure the extensional viscosity of the samples. The measurement temperature was 180℃, and the elongation rates were 0.01, 0.1, and 1 s−1, respectively. Rectangular samples with dimension of 1 mm × 10 mm × 17 mm (thickness × width × length) were prepared via hot compression at 200℃ for 10 min to eliminate the effects of the processing history on the extensional viscosity of the samples.28

sec.title: Foaming process
sec.p:
The foaming process was carried out with the apparatus shown in Figure 1. The samples were sealed in a high-pressure vessel after the air was expelled by CO2. Subsequently, a certain amount of CO2 was injected into the vessel and kept in supercritical state. Then, the vessel was immersed in an oil bath at 170℃ for 30 min. After the sample was melted, the vessel was cooled down to 155℃ (the foaming temperature) at a cooling rate of approximately 3℃ min−1 and maintained for 30 min. The pressure inside the vessel was held at 25 MPa by adjusting a valve. The residence time was long enough for the supercritical CO2 dissolving into the sample.29 Then, the vessel was depressurized to the atmospheric pressure promptly and cooled down in ice water to minimize coalescence. Finally, the foamed samples were removed from the vessel after cooling and stored for two weeks before characterization. The process was repeated three times for each sample. Figure 1.
Illustration of the foaming experiment apparatus in the autoclave.
1: CO2 cylinder; 2, 3, 4: valve; 5: high-pressure vessel; 6: pressure transducer; 7: stirrer; 8: Beckmann’s thermometer; 9: mercury thermometer; 10: constant temperature oil bath.

sec.title: Foam characterization
sec.p: The expansion ratio (Rv) of the foams was defined as the ratio of the density of the unfoamed PP (ρp) to the density of the foamed PP (ρf), as follows (4)Rv=ρpρf

The foam densities (ρf) were measured using the buoyancy method. WA is the weight of the sample in air. WB is the weight of the sample in the suspension liquid. ρ0 is the density of the liquid, and ρL is the density of air. (5)ρf=WAWA-WB(ρ0-ρL)+ρL

The samples were fractured in liquid nitrogen. The microstructures of the foam were characterized by a JSM-6360LV scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The average diameter (D) of the cells was calculated by equation (6), where ni is the number of cells with an equivalent diameter of di (6)D=∑dini∑ni

The cell density N0, defined as the number of cells per unit volume of the unfoamed PP, was calculated by equation (7) as follows5 (7)N0=(nM2A)32×ρpρf where n is the number of cells in the SEM image, M is the magnification of the image, A is the area of the image, ρp is the density of the unfoamed PP, and ρf is the density of the foamed PP. Three SEM images were obtained for different parts of the same sample.

sec.title: Shear rheology
sec.p:
Shear rheology is sensitive to the topological structure of PP macromolecules. The dynamic complex viscosities of the four PP samples are presented in Figure 2. The testing range was between 0.628 and 628 rad s−1. At low angular velocities, the Newton plateau of L-PP Y1600 appeared at 3000 Pa·s, while the other three PPs were still in the transition zone. This result means that the curves for these three PPs were far below their zero shear viscosity, and the HMC-PP had the highest shear viscosity in the testing range. The differences of the shear viscosities became less pronounced at high angular frequencies. Curves of the four PPs converged at high frequencies due to the shear thinning effect. Figure 2.
The complex viscosity of four PP samples.
PP: polypropylenes; L-PP: linear PP; HMC-PP: high-molecular PE component; LCB-PP: long-chain branched PP; C-PP: cross-linked PP.

sec.title: Extensional rheology
sec.p:
The extensional viscosity of the four PP samples with different strain rates as a function of time are shown in Figure 3. For the L-PP, no strain-hardening behavior was observed and its extensional viscosities measured at strain rate 0.01 s−1 overlapped with three times the value of zero shear viscosity η0 (3η0), which demonstrated the accuracy of the experiment. For the sample of the HMC-PP, it only exhibited strain hardening at a low strain rate (0.01 s−1). With the strain rate increasing, strain hardening disappeared, and even the melt of the HMC-PP ruptured before steady flow. In contrast to the HMC-PP, the LCB-PP did not show strain hardening at a strain rate of 0.01 s−1 but this behavior happened at higher strain rates (0.1 and 1 s−1). In the C-PP sample, the strain-hardening behavior could be clearly observed at all strain rates. Figure 3.
Extensional viscosity of four PPs at different strain rates as a function of time; (a) L-PP, (b) HMC-PP, (c) C-PP, and (d) LCB-PP.
PP: polypropylenes; L-PP: linear PP; HMC-PP: high-molecular PE component; LCB-PP: long-chain branched PP; C-PP: cross-linked PP.

According to the definition of the uniaxial extensional viscosity ηE, the extensional stress σE that the melt could sustain during elongation at different strain rates could be obtained using equation (8). The melt strength could be directly estimated by comparing the maximum extensional stress obtained in the extensional experiment. (8)σE=ηE•ɛ·

The calculated results of σE are shown in Figure 4. The stress–strain behaviors of C-PP and L-PP did not vary with the extensional strain rate. For all different strain rates, the C-PP with pronounced strain hardening had the largest extensional stress, while the L-PP with no strain-hardening behavior had low extensional stress that corresponded to its low zero shear viscosity. The stress–strain behaviors of the HMC-PP and LCB-PP changed with the strain rate, leading to the following results: at a low strain rate of 0.01 s−1, HMC-PP could bear more extensional stress than the LCB-PP. However, at a higher strain rate of 1 s−1, the maximum extensional stress of the HMC-PP was lower than that of the LCB-PP. The results showed that the magnitude of extensional stress σE was determined by both the strain-hardening behavior and the zero shear viscosity of the matrix PP. Figure 4.
Melt strengths of four PPs as a function of strain; (a) Extensional stress at a strain rate of 0.01 s−1, and (b) Extensional stress at a strain rate of 1 s−1.
PP: polypropylenes; L-PP: linear PP; HMC-PP: high-molecular PE component; LCB-PP: long-chain branched PP; C-PP: cross-linked PP.

sec.title: Rupture behavior of the melt
sec.p: To obtain low-density foams, it needs to expand the cells without rupturing them. This requires the melt to sustain a certain amount of extensional stress and to endure significant deformation. Using the Considère criterion from the melt extensional experiment, we could analyze the rupture behaviors of polymer melts with different extensional viscosity. The criterion could be expressed as dlnσE/dɛ ≥ 1, and it indicated that a uniaxial elongation of a viscoelastic filament would remain homogeneous until a maximum is obtained in the force curve function of the deformation strain.30

Figure 5 illustrates the applications of the Considère criterion on the PP samples at a strain rate of 1 s−1. Four PPs were divided into two groups on the basis of their different extensional behaviors at strain rate 1 s−1. The curves of L-PP and HMC-PP suggested that the cross-section of the filament kept reducing, and the sample finally fractured (dlnσE/dɛ = 0) before a strain of 3 during stretching. The curves of the LCB-PP and C-PP remained around 1 until the strain was more than 3, which indicated that the filaments deformed uniformly in that range. Thereafter, the polymer filaments failed and ruptured (dlnσE/dɛ = 0) simultaneously at a strain above 3. The rupture of the LCB-PP filament occurred at a strain as large as 3.5. Figure 5.
The Considère criterion of different polymers; (a) PPs without strain hardening, and (b) PPs with strain hardening.
PP: polypropylenes; L-PP: linear PP; HMC-PP: high-molecular PE component; LCB-PP: long-chain branched PP; C-PP: cross-linked PP.

Figure 6 illustrates the different extensional behaviors of two types of PPs according to the Considère criterion results. Compared with L-PP and HMC-PP, the melt of LCB-PP and C-PP deformed more uniformly. Consequently, a larger strain could be obtained. The strain during foam expansion was typically between 3 and 4.31 The rupture behaviors also explained that LCB-PP and C-PP had integrated cell structures with large cell diameters, while L-PP and HMC-PP had many open cells, as shown in the section ‘Foam behaviour’. In fact, the origin of the uniform deformation was also strain hardening, which reduced localized deformation in a thinner part of the sample owing to stress increases.32 Figure 6.
Different melt rupture behaviors at the strain rate 1 s−1; (a) Extension without strain-hardening behavior, and (b) Extension with strain-hardening behavior.

sec.title: Foam behavior
sec.p:
A recommended batch-processing condition (25 MPa, 155℃) for PP samples was adopted to test their foamability.29 The different expansion ratios of the four PP foams are shown in Figure 7. Compared with two L-PP samples, LCB-PP and C-PP attained lager expansion ratios; specifically, the expansion ratios of the C-PP foam reached 55. The expansion ratio of HMC-PP sample was only slightly higher than that of L-PP sample. Figure 7.
Expansion ratios of four different molecular structure PPs.
PP: polypropylenes; L-PP: linear PP; HMC-PP: high-molecular PE component; LCB-PP: long-chain branched PP; C-PP: cross-linked PP.

The difference in the cell structures is shown in Figure 8. For the L-PP foam, scarce cells could be observed because of the collapse of the cell walls. The collapse of the cell wall should occur in the early expansion stage because the numerous unfoamed parts may re-melt and form as the crumbled cell walls. Instead, in the HMC-PP sample, the unfoamed parts disappeared and cells coalesced to produce a large amount of open cells. Only in the C-PP and LCB-PP foams, closed polygonal cell structures could be observed. Figure 8.
SEM images of the fracture surfaces of four PPs; (a) L-PP, (b) HMC-PP, (c) C-PP, and (d) LCB-PP.
PP: polypropylenes; L-PP: linear PP; HMC-PP: high-molecular PE component; LCB-PP: long-chain branched PP; C-PP: cross-linked PP; SEM: scanning electron microscopy.

The cell diameters of the four PP foams determined from the SEM images are shown in Figure 9. Few cells with diameters of about 20 µm were found in the L-PP foams. Both the numbers and diameters of the surviving cells of HMC-PP were larger than those of L-PP. The cell densities of C-PP were about 108 (cells cm−3), and the cell diameters were approximately 61 µm. The LCB-PP had the largest cell diameter of 175 µm, and the cell densities were about 106 (cells cm−3). Figure 9.
Cell diameters and densities of four PP foams.
PP: polypropylenes; L-PP: linear PP; HMC-PP: high-molecular PE component; LCB-PP: long-chain branched PP; C-PP: cross-linked PP.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The foamability of the different PPs was compared by the foaming experiments conducted in the same foam-processing condition. As indicated by the large unfoamed parts most likely consisted of the re-melt of the collapsed cell wall (as observed in the SEM image of L-PP in Figure 8), most cells of the L-PP foam should burst in the early expansion step before solidification step triggered by crystallization. The cells must continue growing without rupturing until they crystallize. Therefore, it is implied that the final cell structure was mainly determined by the rheological properties of the PP in our foaming experiments.

The foaming behaviors of two L-PPs were first investigated. Although the zero shear viscosity of HMC-PP was 20 times more than that of L-PP, the linear HMC-PP only had a slightly larger expansion ratio than the normal L-PP. Furthermore, the extensional rheological properties’ results showed that the linear HMC-PP had clear strain hardening at a strain rate of 0.01 s−1 and then disappeared at higher strain rates. Even the melt ruptured before the sample reached a steady extension state. Thus, at higher testing strain rates, the two L-PPs did not show strain-hardening behaviors. This strain-hardening behavior of the linear HMC-PP at low strain rate seemed to have no significant effect on the foamability as many broken cells were observed in the SEM images, indicating that a fairly large amount of gas escaped into the environment directly without the prevention of the cell walls. Gendron pointed out that the biaxial extensional strain rates were on the order of 1 s−1 in the foaming experiments.31 Taki observed the bubble expansion directly through an in situ observation apparatus to survey the bubble coalescence in the foaming process of PP and determined the strain rate to be approximately 0.1 s−1 at a low CO2 saturation pressure (11 MPa).33 The minor difference in the expansion ratio of these two L-PPs was caused by their distinctive difference in the shear viscosity. Higher shear viscosity provided higher melt strength, which allowed the melt to sustain higher stress, as shown in Figure 4. Therefore, the foam from the linear HMC- PP had more visible cell structures than the L-PP foam, as shown in Figure 8. Higher shear viscosity also reduced the gas diffusion rate in the polymer, and less gas escaped directly to the environment.34 However, the effects of the shear viscosity on the expansion ratio were quite limited.

Compared with the linear HMC-PP, the LCB-PP had a much higher expansion ratio, which owed to its distinct extensional rheological properties, even though its shear viscosity was only half of the linear HMC-PP. Differing from the HMC-PP, LCB-PP did not show much strain hardening at a strain rate of 0.01 s−1. However, the strain-hardening behavior occurred at higher testing strain rates relative to the foaming process. Once strain hardening occurred in the cell expansion step, as we analyzed above, which led to the melt strength of the cell wall increasing exponentially. The extensibility also increased due to more uniform deformation of the melt. From the SEM images, it can be concluded that most gases were wrapped in cellular structure, and a small amount of gas was lost to the environment by diffusing through the cell walls. Therefore, the foams had a large expansion ratio.

Because C-PP had much higher extensional viscosity, its foam had smaller cell diameters (61 µm) than the LCB-PP foam (175 µm). Meanwhile, its higher expansion ratio perhaps is due to its cell density two orders higher than that of the LCB-PP foam. The difference between the foaming behaviors of the two types of foamable PP requires further studies.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The extensional rheological behaviors appropriate for PP foaming were investigated. Compared with the shear rheological properties that affected the foaming process to a less extent, the uniaxial extensional rheological properties played a dominant role in the foaming process. PPs with good foamability must show significant strain-hardening behavior at strain rates (0.1–1 s−1) relevant to the foaming process. The strain hardening that occurred out of the specified range did not contribute to the foamability.

The strain-hardening behavior was essential for the PP foaming process. It was exponentially increasing the maximum stress that the cell walls can sustain and prolonging the extensibility of the cell wall by causing the sample to deform more uniformly. As a result, the cell structure was preserved in the foam expansion step, and most of the gas was trapped in the cells that were intact. Only a small amount of gas escaped into the environment by diffusing through the cell walls, which resulted in PP foams with large expansion ratios.

ack.p: We are thankful to Prof Zhao L; Liu T and Xu ZM of the UNILAB Research Center of Chemical Engineering of East China University of Science and Technology for their assistance.
